column4: Yes, although something I'm not used to: sudo is already configured. On my old distro I always wanted to configure it, but never came around to it.
Well, but the point is: some graphical configuration tools ask for root password, and there my user password is accepted. Isn't that strange?
if they explicitly say "root password", please file a bug; they should mostly say something like "please enter your password to gain root access"
I'll check it to be certain ...
that's what the 'universe' component is for (unsupported, though)
it's basically Debian compiled against Ubuntu
I see, I have to make myself familiar with these main/restricted/universe components, thanks for the hint.
oops, I didn't know that! I thought so because of the component-concept that's driven by Ubuntu.
that use of 'component' comes from the Debian archive layout
unfortunately any time you try to come up with names for different collections of packages, you find there are only so many words to use and name clashes tend to arise ...
I see. And the Linux world hasn't come to an agreement about that yet?
it's not really subject to agreement
there are all sorts of things you want to call things in different contexts
